cards.front: What design pattern defines an object that encapsulates how a set of objects interact?
cards.back: Mediator pattern

cards.front: What is the Memento pattern?
cards.back: Without violating encapsulation, capture and externalize an object's internal state so that the object can be restore to this state later.

cards.front: What design pattern captures and externalize an object's internal state so that the object can be restore to this state later?
cards.back: Memento pattern

cards.front: What is the Observer pattern?
cards.back: Defines a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes state, all its dependents are notified and updated automatically.

cards.front: What design pattern defines a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes state, all its dependents are notified and updated automatically?
cards.back: Observer pattern

cards.front: What is the State pattern?
cards.back: Allows an object to alter its behavior when its internal state changes. The object will appear to change its class.

cards.front: What design pattern allows an object to alter its behavior when its internal state changes?
cards.back: State pattern

cards.front: What is the Strategy pattern?
cards.back: Defines a family of algorithms, encapsulates each one, and makes them interchangeable. Lets the algorithm vary independently from clients that use it.

cards.front: What design pattern defines a family of algorithms, encapsulates each one, and makes them interchangeable, and lets the algorithm vary independently from clients that use it?
cards.back: Strategy pattern

cards.front: What is the Template Method pattern?
cards.back: Defines the skeleton of an algorithm in an operation, deferring some steps to subclasses. Lets subclasses redefine certain steps of an algorithm without changing the algorithm's structure.

cards.front: What design pattern defines the skeleton of an algorithm in an operation, deferring some steps to subclasses?
cards.back: Template Method pattern

cards.front: What is the Visitor pattern?
cards.back: Represents an operation to be performed on the elements of an object structure. Lets you define a new operation without changing the classes of the elements on which it operates.

cards.front: What design pattern represents an operation to be performed on the elements of an object structure and lets you define a new operation without changing the classes of the elements on which it operates?
cards.back: Visitor pattern

cards.front: What is the Adapter pattern?
cards.back: Converts the interface of a class into another interface clients expect. Lets classes work together that couldn't otherwise because of incompatible interfaces.

cards.front: What design pattern converts the interface of a class into another interface clients expect?
cards.back: Adapter pattern

cards.front: What is the Bridge pattern?
cards.back: Decouples an abstraction from its implementation so that the two can vary independently.

cards.front: What design pattern decouples an abstraction from its implementation so that the two can vary independently?
cards.back: Bridge pattern

cards.front: What is the Composite pattern?
cards.back: Compose objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies. Lets clients treat individual objects and compositions of objects uniformly.

cards.front: What design pattern composes objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies?
cards.back: Composite pattern

cards.front: What is the Decorator pattern?
cards.back: Attaches additional responsibilities to an object dynamically. Provides a flexible alternative to sub-classing for extending functionality.

cards.front: What design pattern attaches additional responsibilities to an object dynamically and provides a flexible alternative to sub-classing for extending functionality?
cards.back: Decorator pattern

cards.front: What is the Facade pattern?
cards.back: Provides a unified interface to a set of interfaces in a subsystem. Defines a high-level interface that makes the subsystem easier to use.

cards.front: What design pattern provides a unified interface to a set of interfaces in a subsystem and defines a high-level interface that makes the subsystem easier to use.
cards.back: Facade pattern

cards.front: What is the Flyweight pattern?
cards.back: Uses sharing to support large numbers of fine-grained objects efficiently.

cards.front: What design pattern uses sharing to support large numbers of fine-grained objects efficiently?
cards.back: Flyweight pattern

cards.front: What is the Proxy pattern?
cards.back: Provides a surrogate or placeholder for another object to control access to it.

cards.front: What design pattern provides a surrogate or placeholder for another object to control access to it?
cards.back: Proxy pattern

cards.front: What is the Abstract Factory pattern?
cards.back: Provides an interface for creating families of related or dependent objects without specifying their concrete class.

cards.front: What design pattern provides an interface for creating families of related or dependent objects without specifying their concrete class?
cards.back: Abstract Factory pattern

cards.front: What is the Builder pattern?
cards.back: Separates the construction of a complex object from its representation, so the same construction process can create different representations.

cards.front: What design pattern separates the construction of a complex object from its representation, so the same construction process can create different representations?
cards.back: Builder pattern.

cards.front: What is the Factory Method pattern?
cards.back: (Technically it's an idiom) Defines an interface for creating an object, but lets subclasses decide which class to instantiate. Lets a class defer instantiation to subclasses.

cards.front: What design pattern defines an interface for creating an object, but lets subclasses decide which class to instantiate?
cards.back: Factory method (technically an idiom, not a design pattern)

cards.front: What is the Prototype pattern?
cards.back: Specifies the kinds of objects to create using a prototypical instance, and creates new objects by copying this prototype.

cards.front: What design pattern specifies the kinds of objects to create using a prototypical instance, and creates new objects by copying this prototype?
cards.back: Prototype pattern

cards.front: What is the Singleton pattern?
cards.back: Ensures a class only has one instance and provides a global point of access to it.

cards.front: What design pattern ensures a class only has one instance and provides a global point of access to it?
cards.back: Singleton pattern

cards.front: What are design patterns?
cards.back: Recurring, reusable solutions to common class and class relationship problems.

cards.front: What is the Law of Demeter?
cards.back: Each unit should have only limited knowledge about other units - only units "closely" related to the current unit. Each unit should only talk to friends, not strangers. Only talk to immediate friends.

cards.front: If a cache line size is 64B, and the memory bus is 64 bits wide, how many transfers per cache line?
What does an exclusive cache style?
cards.back: An eviction from L1D pushes the cache line down into L2, which has the same cache line size. Each eviction is progressively more expensive.

cards.front: What manufacturer uses an exclusive cache style?
cards.back: AMD

cards.front: How does an inclusive cache style work?
cards.back: Each cache line in L1D is also in L2. This makes L1D eviction faster.

cards.front: What manufacturer uses an inclusive cache style?
cards.back: Intel

cards.front: What is the Fast Fourier Transform?
cards.back: A fast Fourier transform (FFT) algorithm computes the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) of a sequence, or its inverse. Fourier analysis converts a signal from its original domain (often time or space) to a representation in the frequency domain and vice versa. An FFT rapidly computes such transformations by factorizing the DFT matrix into a product of sparse (mostly zero) factors.

cards.front: What is a skip list?
cards.back: A data structure that allows fast search within an ordered sequence of elements. Fast search is made possible by maintaining a linked hierarchy of subsequences, with each successive subsequence skipping over fewer elements than the previous one. Searching starts in the sparsest subsequence until two consecutive elements have been found, one smaller and one larger than or equal to the element searched for. A skip list is built in layers. The bottom layer is an ordinary ordered linked list. Each higher layer acts as an "express lane" for the lists below, where an element in layer i appears in layer i+1 with some fixed probability p (two commonly used values for p are 1/2 or 1/4).

cards.front: What operations does a skip list support and what is their avg and worst case times?
cards.back: search: O(log n) O(n) insert: O(log n) O(n) delete: O(log n) O(n)

cards.front: What operations does a van Emde Boas tree support and what are the time complexities?
cards.back: All are O(log log M), where M is the total number of items that can be stored = 2^m Or O(log m) where m is the actual number of items stored Space: O(M) Search Insert Delete Predecessor Successor

cards.front: What are the complexities for treap operations?
cards.back: For all the basic maintenance operations, they are O(log n) average case and O(n) worst case. - Search - Insert - Delete For these operations, O(m log n/m) for treaps of sizes m and n, with m ≤ n. - union - intersection - difference

cards.front: What are Catalan numbers?
cards.back: Catalan numbers form a sequence of natural numbers that occur in various counting problems, often involving recursively-defined objects. They can be thought of as the set of balanced parentheses. Do not think of Catalan numbers as pseudoprimes. There are only 3 Catalan pseudoprimes.

cards.front: What is Karatsuba multiplication?
cards.back: It reduces the multiplication of two n-digit numbers to at most n^1.585 single-digit multiplications in general (and exactly n^log(base2)3 when n is a power of 2). The Karatsuba algorithm was the first multiplication algorithm asymptotically faster than the quadratic "grade school" algorithm.

cards.front: What is the time complexity of Ford-Fulkerson?
cards.back: O(E max|f|)

cards.front: Is a geometric Steiner tree NP-Complete?
cards.back: Yes

cards.front: What are the 2 algorithms for convex hull?
cards.back: - Graham scan - Jarvis march (gift-wrapping method)

cards.front: How does a Graham scan work in finding convex hull?
cards.back: At O(n log n), uses a sort and then a simple single pass of all the points, and making only left turns as it goes around the perimeter counter-clockwise. When the next point is a right turn, it backtracks past all points (using a stack and popping points off) until that turn turns into a left turn.

cards.front: How does the Jarvis march work in finding convex hull?
cards.back: Starting with the leftmost point p: Go through each point to the right of that point, and using p as a pivot, find which point is the most clockwise. O(n) Get the most clockwise point as the new p - O(1) Loop again with new p This continues until the starting point is reached O(h) - where h is the number of hull points

cards.front: What is the worst case time complexity of a Jarvis march?
cards.back: O(n^2) Occurs when most points are part of the hull, and few points contained in the hull.

cards.front: What is the average complexity of a Jarvis march?
cards.back: O(n * h) where h is the number of points that compose the hull.

cards.front: What is white-box testing?
cards.back: The tester is using knowledge of the program's internals.

cards.front: What is black-box testing?
cards.back: The tester is testing without knowledge of the internals.

cards.front: What is unit testing?
cards.back: Testing a single module in isolation.

cards.front: What can affect testing, apart from API inputs?
cards.back: - timing of inputs - disk full - network latency - network failures

cards.front: What are 3 situations where timing of inputs important in testing?
cards.back: - when SUT interacts directly with hardware devices - when SUT interfaces with other machines on the network - SUT is multithreaded

cards.front: What is a mock object?
cards.back: An object used to replicate the interfaces and interactions of a larger system that can be bolted on to the SUT.

cards.front: What is integration testing?
cards.back: Testing units together to ensure the integrated behavior performs as expected.

cards.front: What is system testing?
cards.back: - not concerned with internals - does system as a while perform acceptably for the important use cases

cards.front: What is differential testing?
cards.back: Running test inputs into 2 different implementations and then testing for equality. This is useful for testing multiple versions of the software.

cards.front: What is stress testing?
cards.back: Testing code or a system beyond its normal usage. Testing large inputs. Testing many requests.

cards.front: How can you tell you're testing enough?
cards.back: Code coverage metrics (of which there are a few)

cards.front: What does code coverage not tell you?
cards.back: - missing errors of omission - code that misses a specification item - does not tell us that code looped the correct number of times

cards.front: What should you do when you discover that not all code is covered?
cards.back: Don't blindly write tests to cover all cases. Rethink the tests. Perhaps they are interpreting the functionality incorrectly.

cards.front: What are some coverage metrics?
cards.back: - line coverage - statement coverage (multiple statements on a line) - branch coverage - mc/dc coverage - loop coverage

cards.front: What is mc/dc coverage?
cards.back: modified condition / decision - Required for certain types of avionics software - Tests every possible branch and condition

cards.front: What is path coverage?
cards.back: Coverage that is concerned with the paths taken to arrive at a place in the code.

cards.front: What is infeasible code?
cards.back: Code that can never be true. Infeasible code is code that is either not forward- or not backward-reachable. Infeasible code is not necessarily an error but it is a good indicator that something is wrong with the code and, e.g., in avionics, infeasible code is forbidden by current standards.

cards.front: Should you include integration tests in code coverage metrics?
cards.back: No

cards.front: What should you do before fixing a reported bug?
cards.back: Write a test. Avoiding this practice allows bugs to re-appear.

cards.front: Why should tests be idempotent and isolated?
cards.back: It allows tests to be run in any order, re-run, and parallelized.

cards.front: What is a skip list?
cards.back: A data structure for storing a sorted list of items using a hierarchy of linked lists that connect increasingly sparse subsequences of the items. O(log N) expected time for all operations, O(N) worst case.

cards.front: What is a treap?
cards.back: Tree + heap A random priority is assigned to every key and must maintain two properties: - They are in order with respect to their keys, as in a typical binary search tree - They are in heap order with respect to their priorities, that is, no key has a key of lower priority as an ancestor O(log N) expected time for all operations, O(N) worst case.

cards.front: What is a max-heap?
cards.back: A queue in which each element has a "priority" assigned to it. Elements with higher priorities are served before lower priorities.

cards.front: What is a binary heap?
cards.back: A collection of keys arranged in a complete heap-ordered binary tree, represented in level order in an array (not using the first entry). The parent of the node in position k is in position [k/2] and the two children of the node in position k are in position 2k and 2k+1.

cards.front: What is a Adaptable Priority Queue?
cards.back: A priority queue that allows you to change the priority of objects already in the queue.

cards.front: What is a connected graph?
cards.back: There exists a path from every vertex to every other vertex in the graph.

cards.front: What is a tree?
cards.back: An acyclic connected graph.

cards.front: What is a cycle?
cards.back: Path with at least one edge whose first and last vertices are the same.

cards.front: What is a spanning tree?
cards.back: A subgraph that contains all of that graph's vertices and a single tree.

What are heuristics?
cards.back: Any approach to problem solving, learning, or discovery that employs a practical method not guaranteed to be optimal or perfect, but sufficient for the immediate goals. Where finding an optimal solution is impossible or impractical, heuristic methods can be used to speed up the process of finding a satisfactory solution. Heuristics can be mental shortcuts that ease the cognitive load of making a decision. Examples of this method include using a rule of thumb, an educated guess, an intuitive judgment, stereotyping, profiling, or common sense

cards.front: What is stable sorting?
cards.back: Items with the same key are sorted based on their relative position in the original permutation

cards.front: What is another name for a trie?
cards.back: Prefix tree or a radix tree.

cards.front: What is internal sorting?
cards.back: An internal sort is any data sorting process that takes place entirely within the main memory of a computer. This is possible whenever the data to be sorted is small enough to all be held in the main memory. For sorting larger datasets, it may be necessary to hold only a chunk of data in memory at a time, since it won't all fit. The rest of the data is normally held on some larger, but slower medium, like a hard-disk. Any reading or writing of data to and from this slower media can slow the sortation process considerably.

cards.front: What is external sorting?
cards.back: External sorting is a term for a class of sorting algorithms that can handle massive amounts of data. External sorting is required when the data being sorted do not fit into the main memory of a computing device (usually RAM) and instead they must reside in the slower external memory (usually a hard drive). External sorting typically uses a hybrid sort-merge strategy. In the sorting phase, chunks of data small enough to fit in main memory are read, sorted, and written out to a temporary file. In the merge phase, the sorted subfiles are combined into a single larger file. Mergesort is typically preferred.

cards.front: What are 2 advantages of merge sort?
cards.back: - suitable for a linked list - suitable for external sort

cards.front: What is disadvantages of merge sort?
cards.back: Need an extra buffer to hold the merged data

cards.front: What are 3 advantages of heap sort?
cards.back: - don't need recursion - suitable for large data - locality of data

cards.front: What is a disadvantage of heap sort?
cards.back: Usually slower than merge sort and quick sort.

cards.front: What is a articulation vertex?
cards.back: The weakest point in a graph.

cards.front: What is the chromatic number?
cards.back: The smallest number of colors needed for an edge coloring of a graph.

cards.front: What are long-term issues involved in machine learning?
cards.back: - technical debt - lack of clear abstraction barriers - changing anything changes everything - feedback loop - usage based on your model changes the model - attractive nuisance (using a successful model in one domain where it doesn't fit in another) - non-stationarity - stick with current data, or get new, and how much of old data to reuse - tracking data dependencies - where did the data come from, how to get new data

cards.front: What is supervised learning?
cards.back: Supervised learning is the machine learning task of inferring a function from labeled training data. The training data consist of a set of training examples. In supervised learning, each example is a pair consisting of an input object (typically a vector) and a desired output value (also called the supervisory signal).

cards.front: What is a regression problem?
cards.back: One that predicts a continuously valued output. May refer specifically to the estimation of continuous response variables, as opposed to the discrete response variables used in classification.

cards.front: What is a classification problem?
cards.back: The problem of identifying to which of a set of categories (sub-populations) a new observation belongs, on the basis of a training set of data containing observations (or instances) whose category membership is known.

cards.front: What is unsupervised learning?
cards.back: Unsupervised learning is the machine learning task of inferring a function to describe hidden structure from unlabeled data. Since the examples given to the learner are unlabeled, there is no error or reward signal to evaluate a potential solution. This distinguishes unsupervised learning from supervised learning and reinforcement learning.

cards.front: What are the 2 types of problems that utilize supervised learning?
cards.back: Regression and classification

cards.front: In machine learning, what is the symbol m used for?
cards.back: the number of training examples.

cards.front: What is another term for linear regression with one variable?
cards.back: Univariate linear regression

cards.front: What is gradient descent?
cards.back: Gradient descent is a first-order iterative optimization algorithm. To find a local minimum of a cost function using gradient descent, one takes steps proportional to the negative of the gradient (partial derivative or tangent) of the function at the current point.

cards.front: What is it called when all training examples are used to calculate gradient descent?
cards.back: batch gradient descent

cards.front: What is another term for linear regression with multiple variables?
cards.back: Multivariate linear regression

cards.front: Why is feature scaling important?
cards.back: Without feature scaling, it can take gradient descent much longer to find the local minimum. The function may oscillate in small movements for much longer.

cards.front: What is is good range to scale features down to?
cards.back: -1 to +1, or Ng's range: -3 to +3

cards.front: What is mean normalization?
cards.back: A method of scaling a feature's values so that they all fall within a range relative to each other.

cards.front: What is a good range for mean normalization?
How can you calculate mean normalization over a set of features?
cards.back: for each x: xi = (xi - avg(x)) / (max_x - min_x) (max_x - min_x) can be replaced with the standard deviation

cards.front: Given a sufficiently small alpha, what can you expect from gradient descent?
cards.back: That it will eventually converge.

cards.front: What does Andrew Ng use to find an appropriate alpha for gradient descent?
How can you get your data to fit better using higher order terms in linear regression?
cards.back: You can take the data and square it, cube it, etc. x1 = (somevalue)^2 x7 = (somevalue)^4 This is applied to data, not the function. The function still is theta1*x1 + theta2*x2, etc

cards.front: What can affect invertibility in a matrix?
cards.back: - 2 more more features are linearly dependent or redundant (size in meters and size in ft) - remove redundant features - too few training examples (m) to features (n): m <= n (remove some features or use regularization)

cards.front: When can we use the normal equation instead of gradient descent to minimize J(theta)?
cards.back: - when we have fewer than 10,000 features - have to ensure invertibility

cards.front: What does numpy.allclose() do?
cards.back: Returns True if two arrays are element-wise equal within a tolerance.

cards.front: Is feature scaling needed when using the normal equation?
cards.back: No

cards.front: What is the normal equation?
cards.back: An equation that can minimize J(theta), solving for theta, instead of using gradient descent. Also called ordinary least squares (OLS) or linear least squares, it's a method for estimating the unknown parameters in a linear regression model, with the goal of minimizing the sum of the squares of the differences between the observed responses in the given dataset and those predicted by a linear function of a set of explanatory variables.

cards.front: What Python determines the pseudo-inverse of a matrix?
cards.back: numpy.linalg.pinv

cards.front: What is treated as false in Python?
cards.back: • False • None • [] (an empty list) • {} (an empty dict) • "" • set() • 0 • 0.0

cards.front: What is a dot product?
cards.back: The dot product of two vectors is the sum of their componentwise products. v_1 * w_1 + ... + v_n * w_n

cards.front: What is the quantile?
cards.back: The number at a given percentile of the data.

cards.front: What is the mode?
cards.back: Most-common value(s) in a set of data. Could have more than one if there are 2 subsets with the same number of values.

cards.front: What is dispersion?
cards.back: Dispersion refers to measures of how spread out our data is. Typically they’re statistics for which values near zero signify not spread out at all and for which large values (whatever that means) signify very spread out.

cards.front: What is covariance?
cards.back: The mean value of the product of the deviations of two variates from their respective means.

cards.front: What is a random variable?
cards.back: A random variable is a variable whose possible values have an associated probability distribution. A very simple random variable equals 1 if a coin flip turns up heads and 0 if the flip turns up tails. A more complicated one might measure the number of heads observed when flipping a coin 10 times or a value picked from range(10) where each number is equally likely.

cards.front: What is PCA and what is it used for?
cards.back: Principal component analysis. We use it to extract one or more dimensions that capture as much of the variation in the data as possible.

cards.front: What is a model?
cards.back: A specification of a mathematical (or probabilistic) relationship that exists between different variables.

cards.front: What is machine learning?
cards.back: Creating and using models that are learned from data.

cards.front: What is the degree of a vertex?
cards.back: The number of edges incident of the vertex, with loops counted twice.

cards.front: What is quick select?
cards.back: A selection algorithm to find the kth smallest element in an unordered list. Quickselect uses the same overall approach as quicksort, choosing one element as a pivot and partitioning the data in two based on the pivot, accordingly as less than or greater than the pivot. However, instead of recursing into both sides, as in quicksort, quickselect only recurses into one side - the side with the element it is searching for. This reduces the average complexity from O(n log n) to O(n).

cards.front: What is preemption?
cards.back: Preemption is the act of temporarily interrupting a task being carried out by a computer system, without requiring its cooperation, and with the intention of resuming the task at a later time. Such a change is known as a context switch.

cards.front: What is an inverted index?
cards.back: An index data structure storing a mapping from content, such as words or numbers, to its locations in a database file, or in a document or a set of documents (named in contrast to a Forward Index, which maps from documents to content). The purpose of an inverted index is to allow fast full text searches, at a cost of increased processing when a document is added to the database.

cards.front: What is set partition?
cards.back: A partitioning of elements of some universal set into a collection of disjointed subsets. Thus, each element must be in exactly one subset.

cards.front: What is a maximum spanning tree?
cards.back: A spanning tree of a weighted graph having maximum weight. It can be computed by negating the edges and running either Prim's or Kruskal's algorithms.

cards.front: What is a minimum product spanning tree and when would you use it?
cards.back: The cost of a tree is the product of all the edge weights in the tree, instead of the sum of the weights. Since log(a*b) = log(a) + log(b), the minimum spanning tree on a graph whose edge weights are replaced with their logarithms gives the minimum product spanning tree on the original graph. You would use it to minimize the product.

cards.front: What is a rolling hash?
cards.back: A rolling hash (also known as a rolling checksum) is a hash function where the input is hashed in a window that moves through the input. One of the main applications is the Rabin-Karp string search algorithm, which uses the rolling hash.

cards.front: What is the Euclidean GCD algorithm in Python?
What is the Rabin-Karp algorithm?
cards.back: Compute hash codes of each substring whose length is the length of s, such as a function with the property that the hash code of a string is an additive function of each individual character. Get the hash code of a sliding window of characters and compare if the hash matches.

cards.front: What is sharding?
cards.back: Sharding is a type of database partitioning that separates very large databases the into smaller, faster, more easily managed parts called data shards.

cards.front: What is von Neumann Architecture?
cards.back: A model for modern computer organization created by John von Neumann, that had two main features: 1) Both data & instructions are stored in the same place 2) Units that store information are different from units that process information

cards.front: What is the fetch-execute cycle?
cards.back: A 4 part system that describes how actions are performed in the CPU. There are 4 parts to this cycle: 1) Fetch instructions 2) Decode instructions 3) Get data if needed 4) Execute the instructions

cards.front: What does a Control Unit (CU) do?
cards.back: Controls, organizes and deals with all the process and instruction the CPU receives. It is also in charge of the Fetch-Execute Cycle. Has two special purpose registers: the Instruction Register and the Program Counter.

cards.front: What is the time complexity of breadth-first search?
cards.back: O(m + n) uses queue

cards.front: What is the time complexity of breadth-first search?
cards.back: O(m + n) uses stack

cards.front: What is the time and space complexity of minimum edit distance using dynamic programming?
cards.back: Time O(mn) Space O(mn)

cards.front: What is the time complexity of Floyd-Warshall?
cards.back: Theta(n^3)

cards.front: What is the log of n! ?
cards.back: n log n

cards.front: What is the time and space complexity of Bellman-Ford?
cards.back: Time : O (|V| |E|) or Theta(n^3) Space: O (|V|)

cards.front: What is the Bellman–Ford algorithm?
cards.back: An algorithm that computes shortest paths from a single source vertex to all of the other vertices in a weighted digraph. It is slower than Dijkstra's algorithm for the same problem, but more versatile, as it is capable of handling graphs in which some of the edge weights are negative numbers.

cards.front: What is a Hamiltonian cycle?
cards.back: Given an undirected graph G = (V, E), does there exist a simple cycle Γ that contains every node in V ? Certificate is a permutation of the n nodes, contain each node in v exactly once, there is an edge btw each pair of adj nodes in the permutation.

cards.front: What is the set cover problem?
cards.back: Given a set U of elements, a collection S1, S2, ..., Sm of subsets of U, and an integer k, does there exist a collection of ≤ k of these sets whose union is equal to U ?

cards.front: What is the time and space complexity of heapsort?
cards.back: O(n lg n) time O(1) space

cards.front: What is the time and space complexity of merge sort?
cards.back: O(n lg n) time O(n) space

cards.front: How would you divide up a data set for training and testing?
cards.back: Split your data set, so that two-thirds of it is used to train the model, after which we test/measure the model’s performance on the remaining third.

cards.front: How would you split up a data set in order to choose from multiple models?
cards.back: In such a situation, you should split the data into three parts: a training set for building models, a validation set for choosing among trained models (called the cross-validation set), and a test set for judging the final model.

cards.front: What is a Type 1 error?
cards.back: A false positive

cards.front: What is a Type 2 error?
cards.back: A false negative

cards.front: In statistics, how would you calculate precision?
cards.back: true_pos / (true_pos + false_pos)

cards.front: In statistics, how would you calculate recall?
cards.back: true_pos / (true_pos + false_neg)

cards.front: In statistics, what does precision measure?
cards.back: Precision measures how accurate our positive predictions are.

cards.front: In statistics, what does recall measure?
cards.back: Recall measures what fraction of the positives our model identified.

cards.front: How would you calculate the F1 score?
cards.back: 2 * precision * recall / (precision + recall)

cards.front: What is another name for the F1 score?
cards.back: the harmonic mean of precision and recall

cards.front: What is the trade-off between precision and recall?
cards.back: A model that predicts “yes” when it’s even a little bit confident will probably have a high recall but a low precision; a model that predicts “yes” only when it’s extremely confident is likely to have a low recall and a high precision. Alternatively, you can think of this as a trade-off between false positives and false negatives. Saying “yes” too often (high recall) will give you lots of false positives; saying “no” too often will give you lots of false negatives (high precision).

cards.front: High bias and low variance typically correspond to _______.
cards.back: underfitting

cards.front: Low bias but very high variance typically correspond to _______.
cards.back: overfitting

cards.front: What can you do when your model has high bias (which means it performs poorly even on your training data)?
cards.back: One thing to try is adding more features.

cards.front: What can you do if your model suffers from overfitting due to high variance?
cards.back: You can remove features. Another solution is to obtain more training examples (if you can). Or use regularization.

cards.front: What does BFGS stand for?
cards.back: Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno algorithm

cards.front: What is L-BFGS?
cards.back: Limited-memory BFGS (L-BFGS or LM-BFGS) is an optimization algorithm in the family of quasi-Newton methods that approximates the Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno (BFGS) algorithm using a limited amount of computer memory. It is a popular algorithm for parameter estimation in machine learning.

cards.front: What are some alternative algorithms that can optimize for a logistic regression problem?
cards.back: - conjugate gradient - BGFS - L-BGFS

cards.front: What makes neural networks superior over regression or classification?
cards.back: Each hidden layer learns its own features instead of being given features.

cards.front: How should you initialize Theta for a neural network?
cards.back: Initialize as a matrix of random reals between 0 and 1. Constrain within a range of +/- epsilon using Theta * 2*epsilon - epsilon.

cards.front: What are the number of neurons (units) at the input layer of a neural network?
cards.back: The number of features.

cards.front: What are the number of neurons (units) at the output layer of a neural network performing classification?
cards.back: The number of classes you are classifying.

cards.front: How many hidden layers should there be in a neural network?
cards.back: Start with 1 as a default, and if more than one, have the same number of units at each layer. The more the better. The number of units in each hidden layer should be more than, or a multiple of, the input units.

cards.front: Machine learning: What tends to happen with the training error in a linear model as the degree of polynomial increases?
cards.back: The error decreases, but too high a degree of polynomial will cause overfitting.

cards.front: Machine learning: What tends to happen with the cross-validation error in a linear model as the degree of polynomial increases?
cards.back: It starts high (high bias) and decreases, reaching a minimum, and then increases (high variance).
